Checklist

Formatting

Choosing the correct fonts, colours, and formatting ensures legibility and readability for all students.

Best Practice Advice

1. Include Navigation Landmarks: Adding landmarks such as page numbers and proper headings help students using screen readers understand where they are on a page.

2. Don't use colour alone to convey information: Students who are visually impaired or using a screen reader may not be able to decipher between colours.

3. Avoid excessive use of Bold and Italicized Text: Bold and Italics should be only used to highlight important content as students with dyslexia may struggle with italics and screen readers do not interpret bold and Italicized text.

  • Microsoft PowerPoint
  • Microsoft Word
  • Google Slides
  • Google Docs
This workflow includes the following tasks: choosing a font, choosing a colour, inserting hyperlink text, descriptive text.

1. Choosing a Font

Ensures that slides have no distractive or hard to read text for students with ADHD, low vision, dyslexia and more.

Step 1: Highlight your text and select a Sans-Serif Font, for example, Arial, Times New Roman or Calibri. Sans Serif fonts have clean lines and sharp edges to increase readability.

Step 2: It is recommended to use fonts larger than 28-points. Select text and choose a font size of 28 or larger.

Step 3: Rather than having floating text, it is recommended to have the text on slides outlined in a box. To do so select the text box click "Shape Format" then select "Shape Outline" and choose a colour.

2. Choosing a Colour

Ensures that colour is legible and not the only means of conveying message, to accommodate students with visual disabilities like colour blindness.

Step 1: Select your text and choose a high contrast colour in relation to the background from the standard colour options in the Home Menu.


Step 2: Select "Colour" under the Design tab and select "Grayscale" in order to ensure high contrast. This ensures students with colour deficiency are not struggling to interpret colourful portions of your document.

3. Inserting Hyperlink Text

Ensures that students with visual impairments can read and understand what the link is meant to be used for.

Step 1: Prepare a short description of the link in a few words.



Step 2: Highlight the link's description, right click, and select "Hyperlink".



Step 3: Add in the link to the address box and select "ok".

4. Descriptive Text

Best practices advise to use descriptive text in order to ensure that students with visual impairments can understand the overall context of the slide when using screen readers.

Step 1: Select "Text Box" from the home tab, draw the text box at the top of the slide, and describe your slide in a few words.

This workflow includes the following tasks: choosing a colour, inserting hyperlink text, heading structure hierachy.

1. Choosing a Font

Ensures that slides have no distractive or hard to read text for students with ADHD, low vision, dyslexia and more.

Step 1: Highlight your text and select a Sans-Serif Font, for example, Arial, Times New Roman or Calibri. Sans Serif fonts have clean lines and sharp edges to increase readability.

Step 2: It is recommended to use fonts larger than 11-points. Select text and choose a font size of 11 or larger.

2. Choosing a Colour

Ensures that colour is legible and not the only means of conveying message, to accommodate students with visual disabilities.

Step 1: Select your text and choose a high contrast colour in relation to the background from the standard colour options in the Home Menu.


Step 2: Select "Colour" under the Design tab and select "Grayscale" in order to ensure high contrast. This ensures students with colour deficiency are not struggling to interpret colourful portions of your document.

3. Inserting Hyperlink Text

Ensures that students with visual impairments can read and understand what the link is meant to be used for.

Step 1: Prepare a short description of the link in a few words.



Step 2: Highlight the link's description, right click, and select "Hyperlink".



Step 3: Add in the link to the address box and select "ok".

3. Heading structure creates hierarchy

Screen readers and other assistive tchnology users navigate Word documents by heading structure, assuming Word's Heading styles are used. This enables students to navigate between headings and subheadings.

Step 1: Highlight the text you want to apply a heading to

Step 2: Under Home > Styles, select the type of style you would like to apply to the text. E.g. Heading 1

Step 3: A Heading 1 is usually a page title or a main content heading. It is the most important heading, and there is generally just one. A Heading 2 is usually a major section heading.A Heading 3 is usually a sub-section of the Heading 2. A Heading 4 is usually a sub-section of the Heading 3, and so on, ending with Heading 6

Note: One should not skip heading levels, such as using Heading 4 directly below a Heading 2

1. Choosing a Font

Ensures that slides have no distractive or hard to read text for students with ADHD and low vision.

Step 1: Highlight your text and select a Sans-Serif Font, for example, Arial, Times New Roman or Calibri. Sans Serif fonts have clean lines and sharp edges to increase readability.

Step 2: It is recommended to use fonts larger than 11-points. Select text and choose a font size of 11 or larger.

2. Choosing a Colour

Ensures that colour is legible and not the only means of conveying message, to accommodate students with visual disabilities.

Step 1: Select your text and choose a high contrast colour in relation to the background from the standard colour options in the Home Menu.

Ensures that students with visual impairments can read and understand what the link is meant to be used for.

Step 1: Prepare a short description of the link in a few words.



Step 2: Highlight the link's description, right click, and select "Hyperlink".



Step 3: Add in the link to the address box and select "ok".

4. Heading structure creates hierarchy

Screen readers and other assistive tchnology help users navigate Word documents through a heading structure. This enables students to navigate between headings and subheadings.

Step 1: Highlight the text you want to apply a heading to.

Step 2: Under Format > Paragraph Styles, select the type of style you would like to apply to the text. E.g. Heading 1

Step 3: A Heading 1 is usually a page title or a main content heading. It is the most important heading, and there is generally just one. A Heading 2 is usually a major section heading. A Heading 3 is usually a sub-section of the Heading 2. A Heading 4 is usually a sub-section of the Heading 3, and so on, ending with Heading 6.

Note: One should not skip heading levels, such as using Heading 4 directly below a Heading 2.
